result.execSummary:
The defendant Jeremy R Shoemaker was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Bail Jumping-Felony, a class H felony, Wisconsin Statutes 946.49(1)(b).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

records.addlTxt:
3:30 PM Prosecuting attorney Andrew R Polzin in court for the State of Wisconsin.  Defendant Jeremy R Shoemaker in court, in custody.  Attorney Nick Smith in court for Jeremy R Shoemaker. All cases called appearances given.  Victim rights are complied with One victim is appearing Deft enters the following pleas in 21CF188 Count 1 no contest; 20CT47 Count 1 no contest; 21CF79 Count 1 no contest; 22CF78 Count 1 no contest and 22CT5 Count 1- no contest.  Any remaining counts are DRI.  Plea questionnaire reviewed. Clerk directed to enter plea. Factual basis. Court accepts pleas & finds guilty. Voting rights are given in the felony cases.   20TR1373 and 20TR1372 are dismissed.

Court hears from the victim in 21CF79.

Court orders the following;

24 months initial confinement 18 months extended confine
Court Costs and any applicable assessments, fees and surcharges due the court.  A payment plan can be set up with the Clerk's Of Courts for those assessments, fees and surcharges. If payments are not made, a civil judgement, with interest, may be ordered. 
Eligible for the challenge incarceration program  Eligible for the substance abuse program

62 days sentence credit
